heisig_chinese_memo: An old man know when kids are getting too cocky and likes to keep them grounded by smacking them with a walking stick or a spoon. &nbsp
heisig_constituent: old man, old man, soil, dirt, ground, spoon, sitting on the ground
heisig_story: First, do not confuse this character with venerable old man (Frame 849), which is far more rarely used. The character for an old man begins with an abbreviation of the character for somebody, the nose having been shortened into a simple crisscross of lines. But there is another, simpler way to remember it all: the soil drawn first indicates that one has come close to the age when "dust to dust" begins to take on a personal meaning; the diagonal walking stick for getting around; and the spoon for being spoon-fed.

koohiiStory1: An old man, wondering what itÂ´s like in a grave, sits in a freshly dug plot. When a gravekeeper mistakes him for dead and begins burying him with soil, the old man saves himself by flailing his walking stick in the air.
koohiiStory2: Old man sits in the dirt, having a stroke.

WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Imagine yourself digging a coffin hole with nothing but a spoon. Your hands get all cramped, your wrist starts to hurt, and you get painful blisters on your hands. It takes forever to dig a hole big enough for a coffin!

humanum_full_description_en:
A Bronze shape similar to the inscriptions crutches writing " dagger " shape, " dagger " and falsely written " stop ." In addition, the upper part of the word " Lao " has changed a lot since the Spring and Autumn Period (see Qi Dazai's return to his father's plate, Shushi Zhong, etc.). Among them, the upper part of the word " Lao " in the mourning is "you", which is suspected to be the sound symbol of " Lao ".

The Oracle " Lao " is used as the place name, "Collection" 22246: "Broom (women) Jiacai (Zai) Lao."

" Lao " in bronze is used as the original meaning, referring to the elderly, the father of San Jiliang: "Use wine for the sake of decency, and use you to enjoy the filial piety to your brothers, marry you (women), and those who are old." Used as an adjective, referring to old age, calling the white tiger for five years: "Yu Lao", that is, I am old (Lin Yuan). It also refers to the elder and important minister of the country, the king of Zhongshan Fanghu: "The emperor does not forget his honor, and [è¾¶å] his old strategy rewards the middle (zhong) father", which means that the emperor has not forgotten his merits, so that the elderly ministers will be honored. The father's merits and rewards are written on bamboo slips. The word is also used as " test ", referring to the father, Qingmao: "Qing Zhajue Lao (Kao) respects Yi."

The word " old " in the Warring States period refers to old age, "Shangbo Zhushu II. "Rong Chengshi" Jane 17: "Shun is an old man, he is unclear, but the saint (listens) is not clong." Also "Tsinghua Jane II. Jane 72-73 of "The Year of the Relations": "Qi Hou is also the power of the old man." The term "old man" does not necessarily refer to his old age. As the meaning of the word " Lao " gradually becomes fictitious, in the handed down documents, " Lao " may be added to the title of someone or something and used as a prefix, such as "Northern Qi Shu. The Legend of The Scholars. "Shi Yao": "This is an old stone machine, chat as a gift."

"Said Wen": "Old, test. Seventy means old. From people, hair, and daggers. The beard and hair of words turn white. All the old belong to the old." According to "Shu Wen Jie Zi Shu" mentioned For those who transfer notes, create a genre, agree to accept each other, take the test, and always do." The words " kao " and " old " are regarded as "transfer notes". Since "Shuowen" did not fully clarify the relationship between the two characters, the meaning of re-annotation has been divergent. Sun Yong long people today proposed a new solution of the more thoughtful, detailed " examination ."

Heisig: First, do not confuse this character with venerable old man (Frame 849), which is far more rarely used. The character for an old man begins with an abbreviation of the character for somebody, the nose having been shortened into a simple crisscross of lines. But there is another, simpler way to remember it all: the soil drawn first indicates that one has come close to the age when "dust to dust" begins to take on a personal meaning; the diagonal walking stick for getting around; and the spoon for being spoon-fed.
* As a primitive, the meaning is the same, but the final two strokes are omitted so that they can be replaced with other elements.
